title: Dwarf Galaxies with Optical Signatures of Active Massive Black Holes
abstract: We present a sample of 151 dwarf galaxies (10<SUP>8.5</SUP> <~ M <SUB>sstarf</SUB> <~ 10<SUP>9.5</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>) that exhibit optical spectroscopic signatures of accreting massive black holes (BHs), increasing the number of known active galaxies in this stellar-mass range by more than an order of magnitude. Utilizing data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 8 and stellar masses from the NASA-Sloan Atlas, we have systematically searched for active BHs in ~25,000 emission-line galaxies with stellar masses comparable to the Magellanic Clouds and redshifts z < 0.055. Using the narrow-line [O III]/Hβ versus [N II]/Hα diagnostic diagram, we find photoionization signatures of BH accretion in 136 galaxies, a small fraction of which also exhibit broad Hα emission. For these broad-line active galactic nucleus (AGN) candidates, we estimate BH masses using standard virial techniques and find a range of 10<SUP>5</SUP> <~ M <SUB>BH</SUB> <~ 10<SUP>6</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB> and a median of M <SUB>BH</SUB> ~ 2 × 10<SUP>5</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>. We also detect broad Hα in 15 galaxies that have narrow-line ratios consistent with star-forming galaxies. Follow-up observations are required to determine if these are true type 1 AGN or if the broad Hα is from stellar processes. The median absolute magnitude of the host galaxies in our active sample is M<SUB>g</SUB> = -18.1 mag, which is ~1-2 mag fainter than previous samples of AGN hosts with low-mass BHs. This work constrains the smallest galaxies that can form a massive BH, with implications for BH feedback in low-mass galaxies and the origin of the first supermassive BH seeds.

search_results.title: Hundreds of Low-mass Active Galaxies in the Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA) Survey
search_results.abstract: We present an entirely new sample of 388 low-mass galaxies (M <SUB>⋆</SUB> ≤ 10<SUP>10</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>) that have spectroscopic signatures indicating the presence of massive black holes (BHs) in the form of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) or tidal disruption events. Of these, 70 have stellar masses in the dwarf galaxy regime with 10<SUP>8</SUP> ≲ M <SUB>⋆</SUB>/M <SUB>⊙</SUB> ≲ 10<SUP>9.5</SUP>. We identify the active galaxies by analyzing optical spectra of a parent sample of ~23,000 low-mass emission-line galaxies in the Galaxy and Mass Assembly (GAMA) Survey Data Release 4, and employing four different diagnostics based on narrow emission-line ratios and the detection of high-ionization coronal lines. We find that 47 of the 388 low-mass active galaxies exhibit broad Hα in their spectra, corresponding to virial BH masses in the range M <SUB>BH</SUB> ~ 10<SUP>5.0-7.7</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB> with a median BH mass of <M <SUB>BH</SUB>> ~ 10<SUP>6.2</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>. Our sample extends to higher redshifts (z ≤ 0.3; <z> = 0.13) than previous samples of AGNs in low-mass/dwarf galaxies based on Sloan Digital Sky Survey spectroscopy, which can be attributed to the spectroscopic limit of GAMA being ~2 mag deeper. Moreover, our multi-diagnostic approach has revealed low-mass active galaxies spanning a wide range of properties, from blue star-forming dwarfs to luminous "miniquasars" powered by low-mass BHs. As such, this work has implications for BH seeding and AGN feedback at low masses.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is highly relevant to the main paper as it also focuses on finding low-mass active galactic nuclei (AGN) in dwarf galaxies using emission line diagnostics from the GAMA survey. The methodology and goals align closely with the main paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is highly relevant. It focuses on identifying low-mass galaxies with AGN signatures, similar to the main paper. The abstract explicitly mentions dwarf galaxies and the search for massive black holes using spectroscopic signatures. The stellar mass range considered aligns with the main paper. The use of emission-line diagnostics further strengthens the relevance.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Highly relevant. The paper identifies low-mass AGNs in dwarf galaxies using multi-diagnostic emission-line analysis and virial BH mass estimates, directly aligning with the main paper's focus on optical signatures of AGNs in low-mass galaxies. The methodology (SDSS data, emission-line diagnostics, broad Hα) and mass range (10^5-10^6 M⊙) closely match the main paper.
search_results.consensus_explanation: This result directly addresses the main paper's focus on identifying AGNs in low-mass, low-metallicity dwarf galaxies using optimized optical emission line diagnostics.

search_results.title: Relations between Central Black Hole Mass and Total Galaxy Stellar Mass in the Local Universe
search_results.abstract: Scaling relations between central black hole (BH) mass and host galaxy properties are of fundamental importance to studies of BH and galaxy evolution throughout cosmic time. Here we investigate the relationship between BH mass and host galaxy total stellar mass using a sample of 262 broad-line active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in the nearby universe (z < 0.055), as well as 79 galaxies with dynamical BH masses. The vast majority of our AGN sample is constructed using Sloan Digital Sky Survey spectroscopy and searching for Seyfert-like narrow-line ratios and broad Hα emission. BH masses are estimated using standard virial techniques. We also include a small number of dwarf galaxies with total stellar masses M<SUB>stellar</SUB> ≲ 10<SUP>9.5</SUP> M<SUB>⊙</SUB> and a subsample of the reverberation-mapped AGNs. Total stellar masses of all 341 galaxies are calculated in the most consistent manner feasible using color-dependent mass-to-light ratios. We find a clear correlation between BH mass and total stellar mass for the AGN host galaxies, with M<SUB>BH</SUB> ∝ M<SUB>stellar</SUB>, similar to that of early-type galaxies with dynamically detected BHs. However, the relation defined by the AGNs has a normalization that is lower by more than an order of magnitude, with a BH-to-total stellar mass fraction of M<SUB>BH</SUB>/M<SUB>stellar</SUB> ∼ 0.025% across the stellar mass range 10<SUP>8</SUP> ≤ M<SUB>stellar</SUB>/M<SUB>⊙</SUB> ≤ 10<SUP>12</SUP>. This result has significant implications for studies at high redshift and cosmological simulations in which stellar bulges cannot be resolved.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is relevant as it investigates the relationship between black hole mass and total stellar mass of the host galaxy using a sample of broad-line AGN, including some in dwarf galaxies. However, it does not specifically focus on optimizing emission line diagnostics for low-metallicity dwarfs like the main paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is relevant as it explores the relationship between black hole mass and host galaxy stellar mass, a topic related to the main paper's focus on dwarf galaxies hosting massive black holes. While it doesn't exclusively focus on dwarf galaxies, it includes them in the sample and uses similar methods (SDSS spectroscopy, virial BH mass estimation). The inclusion of AGNs and low-mass BHs connects it to the main paper.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Relevant but broader in scope. While it investigates BH-galaxy scaling relations and includes low-mass BHs, the focus is on the M_BH-M_stellar relation across all masses rather than specifically identifying AGNs in dwarfs. The overlap in BH mass range and use of SDSS data make it partially aligned.
search_results.consensus_explanation: While this result explores AGN signatures in dwarf galaxies, its focus on X-ray and radio data is less directly aligned with the main paper's emphasis on optical diagnostics.

search_results.title: JADES: The diverse population of infant black holes at 4 < z < 11: Merging, tiny, poor, but mighty
search_results.abstract: Spectroscopy with the James Webb Space Telescope has opened the possibility of identifying moderate-luminosity active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in the early Universe, at and beyond the epoch of re-ionisation, complementing previous surveys of much more luminous (and much rarer) quasars. We present 12 new AGNs at 4 < z < 7 in the JADES survey (in addition to the previously identified AGN in GN-z11 at z = 10.6) revealed through the detection of a broad-line region (BLR) seen in the Balmer emission lines. The depth of JADES, together with the use of three different spectral resolutions, enables us to probe a lower-mass regime relative to previous studies. In a few cases, we find evidence for two broad components of Hα, which suggests that these could be candidate merging black holes (BHs), although a complex BLR geometry cannot be excluded. The inferred BH masses range from 8 × 10<SUP>7</SUP> M<SUB>⊙</SUB> down to 4 × 10<SUP>5</SUP> M<SUB>⊙</SUB>, interestingly probing the regime expected for direct collapse BHs. The inferred AGN bolometric luminosities (∼10<SUP>44</SUP> ‑ 10<SUP>45</SUP> erg/s) imply accretion rates that are < 0.5 times the Eddington rate in most cases. However, small BHs, with M<SUB>BH</SUB> ∼ 10<SUP>6</SUP> M<SUB>⊙</SUB>, tend to accrete at Eddington or super-Eddington rates. These BHs at z ∼ 4–11 are over-massive relative to their host galaxies' stellar masses when compared to the local M<SUB>BH</SUB> ‑ M<SUB>star</SUB> relation, even approaching M<SUB>BH</SUB> ∼ M<SUB>star</SUB>, as was expected from heavy BH seeds and/or super-Eddington accretion scenarios. However, we find that these early BHs tend to be more consistent with the local relation between M<SUB>BH</SUB> and velocity dispersion, as well as between M<SUB>BH</SUB> and dynamical mass, suggesting that these are more fundamental and universal relations. On the classical, optical narrow-line excitation-diagnostic diagrams, these AGNs are located in the region that is locally occupied by star-forming galaxies, implying that they would be missed by the standard classification techniques if they did not display broad lines. Their location on the diagram is consistent with what is expected for AGNs hosted in metal-poor galaxies (Z ∼ 0.1 ‑ 0.2 Z<SUB>⊙</SUB>). The fraction of broad-line AGNs with L<SUB>AGN</SUB> > 10<SUP>44</SUP> erg/s among galaxies in the redshift range of 4 < z < 6 is about 10%, suggesting that the contribution of AGNs and their hosts to the re-ionisation of the Universe is > 10%.
search_results.claude_explanation: While this result discusses AGN at high redshifts and their contribution to reionization, it does not directly relate to the methodology of identifying AGN in low-metallicity dwarf galaxies using optimized emission line diagnostics, which is the main focus of the paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is relevant due to its focus on identifying accreting supermassive black holes. Although it is at a higher redshift than the main paper, it still touches upon similar methodologies such as emission line detection and black hole mass estimation. The result discusses the location of these AGNs on the narrow-line excitation-diagnostic diagrams, which is directly relevant to the main paper's methodology.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Partially relevant. The paper studies low-mass BHs at high redshift (z=4-11) using JWST, which differs from the main paper's local universe focus. However, the discussion of BH over-massiveness relative to hosts and challenges in optical diagnostics (e.g., metal-poor AGNs) connects to the main paper's themes.
search_results.consensus_explanation: While this result discusses metal-poor AGN spectra and diagnostic challenges at high redshifts, which are relevant to the main paper's goals, the different cosmic epoch and environmental conditions may limit the direct applicability of its findings to the local dwarf galaxy population targeted by the main paper.

search_results.title: A Uniformly Selected Sample of Low-mass Black Holes in Seyfert 1 Galaxies
search_results.abstract: We have conducted a systematic search of low-mass black holes (BHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with broad Hα emission lines, aiming at building a homogeneous sample that is more complete than previous ones for fainter, less highly accreting sources. For this purpose, we developed a set of elaborate, automated selection procedures and applied it uniformly to the Fourth Data Release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. Special attention is given to AGN-galaxy spectral decomposition and emission-line deblending. We define a sample of 309 type 1 AGNs with BH masses in the range 8 × 10<SUP>4</SUP>-2 × 10<SUP>6</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB> (with a median of 1.2 × 10<SUP>6</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>), using the virial mass estimator based on the broad Hα line. About half of our sample of low-mass BHs differs from that of Greene & Ho, with 61 of them discovered here for the first time. Our new sample picks up more AGNs with low accretion rates: the Eddington ratios of the present sample range from <~ 0.01 to ~1, with 30% below 0.1. This suggests that a significant fraction of low-mass BHs in the local universe are accreting at low rates. The host galaxies of the low-mass BHs have luminosities similar to those of L* field galaxies, optical colors of Sbc spirals, and stellar spectral features consistent with a continuous star formation history with a mean stellar age of less than 1 Gyr.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is relevant as it presents a uniformly selected sample of low-mass black holes in Seyfert 1 galaxies using emission line diagnostics from SDSS. However, it does not specifically optimize the diagnostics for low-metallicity dwarf galaxies like the main paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is relevant because it discusses a systematic search for low-mass black holes in active galactic nuclei using broad Hα emission lines. The use of SDSS data and virial mass estimation techniques aligns well with the main paper's approach. The focus on low-mass BHs makes it a relevant contribution.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Highly relevant. This work systematically identifies low-mass BHs in Seyfert 1 galaxies using SDSS, virial mass estimates, and optical diagnostics. The sample (M_BH ~10^5-10^6 M⊙) and focus on AGN selection in low-mass hosts closely mirror the main paper's goals.
search_results.consensus_explanation: This result investigates AGN scaling relations, which could provide a broader context for interpreting the main paper's findings, but its generality makes it less directly relevant to the specific challenges of identifying AGNs in low-mass, low-metallicity dwarf galaxies.

search_results.title: Black Holes At the Centers of Nearby Dwarf Galaxies
search_results.abstract: Using a distance-limited portion of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Data Release 7, we have identified 28 active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in nearby (d≤slant 80 Mpc) low-mass, low-luminosity dwarf galaxies. The accreting objects at the galaxy centers are expected to be intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) with {{M}<SUB>BH</SUB>}≤slant {{10}<SUP>6</SUP>} {{M}<SUB>⊙ </SUB>}. The AGNs were selected using several optical emission-line diagnostics after careful modeling of the continuum present in the spectra. We have limited our survey to objects with spectral characteristics similar to those of Seyfert nuclei, excluding emission-line galaxies with ambiguous spectra that could be powered by stellar processes. Thus, as a set, the host galaxies in our sample are the least massive objects in the very local universe certain to contain central black holes. Our sample is dominated by narrow-line (type 2) AGNs, and it appears to have a much lower fraction of broad-line objects than that observed for luminous, optically selected Seyfert galaxies. Given our focus on the nearest objects included in the SDSS, our survey is more sensitive to low-luminosity emission than previous optical searches for AGNs in low-mass galaxies. The [O iii] λ 5007 luminosities of the Seyfert nuclei in our sample have a median value of {{L}<SUB>5007</SUB>}=2× {{10}<SUP>5</SUP>} {{L}<SUB>⊙ </SUB>} and extend down to ∼ {{10}<SUP>4</SUP>} {{L}<SUB>⊙ </SUB>}. Using published data for broad-line IMBH candidates, we have derived an [O iii] bolometric correction of log ({{L}<SUB>bol</SUB>}/{{L}<SUB>5007</SUB>})=3.0+/- 0.3, which is significantly lower than values obtained for high-luminosity AGNs. Applying this correction to our sample, we obtain minimum black hole mass estimates that fall mainly in the 10<SUP>3</SUP> {{M}<SUB>⊙ </SUB>}-10<SUP>4</SUP> {{M}<SUB>⊙ </SUB>} range, which is roughly where the predicted mass functions for different black hole seed formation scenarios overlap the most. In the stellar mass range that includes the bulk of the AGN host galaxies in our sample, we derive a lower limit on the AGN fraction of a few percent, indicating that active nuclei in dwarf galaxies are not as rare as previously thought.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is highly relevant as it focuses on identifying AGN in nearby low-mass dwarf galaxies using emission line diagnostics from SDSS, which aligns closely with the goals and methodology of the main paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is highly relevant. It focuses specifically on identifying AGNs in nearby dwarf galaxies using optical emission-line diagnostics, mirroring the main paper's objective and methodology. The mention of intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) and the focus on the least massive objects containing central black holes make it highly aligned with the main paper.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Highly relevant. This study confirms AGNs in nearby dwarfs using SDSS emission-line diagnostics and discusses BH masses (10^3-10^4 M⊙) and AGN fractions, directly addressing the main paper's focus on optical signatures of low-mass BHs in dwarfs.

search_results.title: Multi-epoch Spectroscopy of Dwarf Galaxies with AGN Signatures: Identifying Sources with Persistent Broad Hα Emission
search_results.abstract: We use time-domain optical spectroscopy to distinguish between broad emission lines powered by accreting black holes (BHs) and stellar processes (I.e., supernovae) for 16 galaxies identified as active galactic nucleus (AGN) candidates by Reines et al (2013). Our study is primarily focused on those objects with narrow emission line ratios dominated by star formation, for which the origin of the broad Hα emission was unclear. Based on follow-up spectroscopy, we find that the broad Hα emission has faded or was ambiguous for all of the star-forming objects (14/16), over baselines ranging from 5-14 years, suggesting a transient stellar process was responsible for the broad emission in previous Sloan Digital Sky Survey observations. For the two objects in our follow-up sample with narrow-line AGN signatures (RGG 9 and RGG 119), we find persistent broad Hα emission consistent with an AGN origin. Additionally, we use high spectral resolution observations to measure stellar velocity dispersions for 15 objects in the Reines et al. (2013) sample, all with narrow-line ratios indicating the presence of an AGN. Stellar masses range from ∼ 5× {10}<SUP>8</SUP> to 3× {10}<SUP>9</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>, and we measure {σ }<SUB>* </SUB> in the range of 28{--}71 {km} {{{s}}}<SUP>-1</SUP>. These {σ }<SUB>* </SUB> correspond to some of the lowest-mass galaxies with optical signatures of AGN activity. We show that RGG 119, the one object that has both a measured {σ }<SUB>* </SUB> and persistent broad Hα emission, falls near the extrapolation of the {\text{}}{M}<SUB>{BH</SUB>}-{σ }<SUB>\star </SUB> relation to the low-mass end.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is somewhat relevant as it uses time-domain spectroscopy to distinguish between AGN and stellar processes for broad emission lines in dwarf galaxies, including some from the Reines et al. (2013) sample used in the main paper. However, it does not directly optimize emission line diagnostics for low-metallicity dwarfs.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is highly relevant. It uses multi-epoch spectroscopy to confirm the AGN nature of candidate dwarf galaxies, building directly upon the work of Reines et al. (2013), which is likely the source of the main paper. The mention of persistent broad Hα emission and the measurement of stellar velocity dispersions in low-mass galaxies are strong indicators of relevance. The objects studied are directly related to those identified as AGN candidates in the main paper.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Relevant but narrower in focus. The paper evaluates transient vs. persistent broad Hα emission in dwarf AGN candidates, addressing a specific uncertainty in the main paper's methodology. While critical for validation, it is a follow-up study rather than a primary identification effort.

search_results.title: A New Sample of (Wandering) Massive Black Holes in Dwarf Galaxies from High-resolution Radio Observations
search_results.abstract: We present a sample of nearby dwarf galaxies with radio-selected accreting massive black holes (BHs), the majority of which are non-nuclear. We observed 111 galaxies using sensitive, high-resolution observations from the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA) in its most extended A-configuration at X band (∼8-12 GHz), yielding a typical angular resolution of ∼0.″25 and rms noise of ∼15 μJy. Our targets were selected by crossmatching galaxies with stellar masses M <SUB>⋆</SUB> ≤ 3 × 10<SUP>9</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB> and redshifts z < 0.055 in the NASA-Sloan Atlas with the VLA Faint Images of the Radio Sky at Twenty centimeters Survey. With our new high-resolution VLA observations, we detect compact radio sources toward 39 galaxies and carefully evaluate possible origins for the radio emission, including thermal H II regions, supernova remnants, younger radio supernovae, background interlopers, and active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in the target galaxies. We find that 13 dwarf galaxies almost certainly host active massive BHs, despite the fact that only one object was previously identified as having optical signatures of an AGN. We also identify a candidate dual radio AGN in a more massive galaxy system. The majority of the radio-detected BHs are offset from the center of the host galaxies, with some systems showing signs of interactions/mergers. Our results indicate that massive BHs need not always live in the nuclei of dwarf galaxies, confirming predictions from simulations. Moreover, searches attempting to constrain BH seed formation using observations of dwarf galaxies need to account for such a population of “wandering” BHs.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is highly relevant as it presents a new sample of accreting massive black holes in nearby dwarf galaxies identified through high-resolution radio observations, which complements the optical emission line diagnostics used in the main paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is relevant as it identifies massive black holes in dwarf galaxies, although using a different selection method (radio observations). The discovery of non-nuclear BHs and the discussion of BH seed formation are related to the main paper's themes. The mention of dwarf galaxy stellar masses being less than 3e9 Msun is also relevant.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Partially relevant. The radio-based identification of off-nuclear BHs in dwarfs introduces a complementary method but diverges from the main paper's optical diagnostics. The focus on non-nuclear BHs is novel but less aligned with the main paper's central theme.

search_results.title: X-ray and Ultraviolet Properties of AGNs in Nearby Dwarf Galaxies
search_results.abstract: We present new Chandra X-ray Observatory and Hubble Space Telescope observations of eight optically selected broad-line active galactic nucleus (AGN) candidates in nearby dwarf galaxies (z < 0.055). Including archival Chandra observations of three additional sources, our sample contains all 10 galaxies from Reines et al. (2013) with both broad Hα emission and narrow-line AGN ratios (six AGNs, four composites), as well as one low-metallicity dwarf galaxy with broad Hα and narrow-line ratios characteristic of star formation. All 11 galaxies are detected in X-rays. Nuclear X-ray luminosities range from L <SUB>0.5-7keV</SUB> ≈ 5 × 10<SUP>39</SUP> to 1 × 10<SUP>42</SUP> ergs<SUP>-1</SUP>. In all cases except for the star-forming galaxy, the nuclear X-ray luminosities are significantly higher than would be expected from X-ray binaries, providing strong confirmation that AGNs and composite dwarf galaxies do indeed host actively accreting black holes (BHs). Using our estimated BH masses (which range from ∼7 × 10<SUP>4</SUP> to 1 × 10<SUP>6</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>), we find inferred Eddington fractions ranging from ∼0.1% to 50%, I.e., comparable to massive broad-line quasars at higher redshift. We use the HST imaging to determine the ratio of UV to X-ray emission for these AGNs, finding that they appear to be less X-ray luminous with respect to their UV emission than more massive quasars (I.e., α <SUB>OX</SUB> values an average of 0.36 lower than expected based on the relation between α <SUB>OX</SUB> and 2500 Å luminosity). Finally, we discuss our results in the context of different accretion models onto nuclear BHs.
search_results.claude_explanation: This result is highly relevant as it presents X-ray and UV observations of the optically-selected AGN candidates in dwarf galaxies from the Reines et al. (2013) sample, which is also used in the main paper. It provides additional evidence for the presence of accreting black holes in these systems.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is relevant because it confirms the presence of actively accreting black holes in dwarf galaxies using X-ray and UV observations. It builds upon the optical selection of Reines et al. (2013) and provides further evidence for the AGN nature of these sources. The mention of BH masses and Eddington fractions aligns with the main paper's interests.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Highly relevant. This work confirms AGNs in dwarfs using X-ray/UV data, validating optical signatures. The overlap in sample selection (Reines et al. 2013) and BH mass range (10^4-10^6 M⊙) strongly supports the main paper's findings.

search_results.title: RESOLVE and ECO: Finding Low-metallicity z   0 Dwarf AGN Candidates Using Optimized Emission-line Diagnostics
search_results.abstract: Existing star-forming vs. active galactic nucleus (AGN) classification schemes using optical emission-line diagnostics mostly fail for low-metallicity and/or highly star-forming galaxies, missing AGN in typical z ~ 0 dwarfs. To recover AGN in dwarfs with strong emission lines (SELs), we present a classification scheme optimizing the use of existing optical diagnostics. We use Sloan Digital Sky Survey emission-line catalogs overlapping the volume- and mass-limited REsolved Spectroscopy Of a Local VolumE (RESOLVE) and Environmental COntex (ECO) surveys to determine the AGN percentage in SEL dwarfs. Our photoionization grids show that the [O III]/Hβ versus [S II]/Hα diagram (S II plot) and [O III]/Hβ versus [O I]/Hα diagram (O I plot) are less metallicity sensitive and more successful in identifying dwarf AGN than the popular [O III]/Hβ versus [N II]/Hα diagnostic (N II plot or "BPT diagram"). We identify a new category of "star-forming AGN" (SF-AGN) classified as star-forming by the N II plot but as AGN by the S II and/or O I plots. Including SF-AGN, we find the z ~ 0 AGN percentage in dwarfs with SELs to be ~3%-16%, far exceeding most previous optical estimates (~1%). The large range in our dwarf AGN percentage reflects differences in spectral fitting methodologies between catalogs. The highly complete nature of RESOLVE and ECO allows us to normalize strong emission-line galaxy statistics to the full galaxy population, reducing the dwarf AGN percentage to ~0.6%-3.0%. The newly identified SF-AGN are mostly gas-rich dwarfs with halo mass <10<SUP>11.5</SUP> M <SUB>⊙</SUB>, where highly efficient cosmic gas accretion is expected. Almost all SF-AGN also have low metallicities (Z ≲ 0.4 Z <SUB>⊙</SUB>), demonstrating the advantage of our method.
search_results.claude_explanation: This is the main paper being evaluated.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is highly relevant as it proposes an improved method to find AGN in dwarf galaxies with low metallicity. The use of RESOLVE and ECO surveys and the discussion of emission line diagnostics are highly relevant and the paper directly addresses the limitations of standard techniques in identifying dwarf AGN.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Highly relevant. This paper develops optimized emission-line diagnostics (e.g., [S II]/Hα and [O I]/Hα diagrams) to identify dwarf AGNs, directly addressing the main paper's methodological core. The focus on low-metallicity AGNs and SF-AGN classification is closely aligned.

search_results.title: A CEERS Discovery of an Accreting Supermassive Black Hole 570 Myr after the Big Bang: Identifying a Progenitor of Massive z > 6 Quasars
search_results.abstract: We report the discovery of an accreting supermassive black hole at z = 8.679. This galaxy, denoted here as CEERS_1019, was previously discovered as a Lyα-break galaxy by Hubble with a Lyα redshift from Keck. As part of the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science (CEERS) survey, we have observed this source with JWST/NIRSpec, MIRI, NIRCam, and NIRCam/WFSS and uncovered a plethora of emission lines. The Hβ line is best fit by a narrow plus a broad component, where the latter is measured at 2.5σ with an FWHM ~1200 km s<SUP>-1</SUP>. We conclude this originates in the broadline region of an active galactic nucleus (AGN). This is supported by the presence of weak high-ionization lines (N V, N IV], and C III]), as well as a spatial point-source component. The implied mass of the black hole (BH) is log (M <SUB>BH</SUB>/M <SUB>⊙</SUB>) = 6.95 ± 0.37, and we estimate that it is accreting at 1.2 ± 0.5 times the Eddington limit. The 1-8 μm photometric spectral energy distribution shows a continuum dominated by starlight and constrains the host galaxy to be massive (log M/M<SUB>⊙</SUB> ~9.5) and highly star-forming (star formation rate, or SFR ~ 30 M<SUB>⊙</SUB> yr<SUP>-1</SUP>; log sSFR ~ - 7.9 yr<SUP>-1</SUP>). The line ratios show that the gas is metal-poor (Z/Z <SUB>⊙</SUB> ~ 0.1), dense (n <SUB> e </SUB> ~ 10<SUP>3</SUP> cm<SUP>-3</SUP>), and highly ionized (log U ~ - 2.1). We use this present highest-redshift AGN discovery to place constraints on BH seeding models and find that a combination of either super-Eddington accretion from stellar seeds or Eddington accretion from very massive BH seeds is required to form this object.
search_results.claude_explanation: While this result discusses the discovery of a high-redshift AGN, it does not directly relate to the methodology of identifying AGN in low-metallicity dwarf galaxies using optimized emission line diagnostics, which is the main focus of the paper.
search_results.gemini_explanation: This result is somewhat relevant as it focuses on a high redshift object. Although this paper describes the discovery of an accreting supermassive black hole, it is found at a much higher redshift (z = 8.679) than the dwarf galaxies studied in the main paper (z < 0.055) and, while it touches on similar topics, does not have a specific focus on dwarf galaxies or black hole mass estimates in local galaxies.
search_results.deepseek_explanation: Marginally relevant. While it discusses a low-mass BH (log M_BH ~6.95) in a high-redshift galaxy, the focus on z=8.679 and JWST data diverges from the main paper's local universe context. The connection to BH seeding is tangential.
